553.title: Bayes' rule: Explore
553.text:
Bayes' rule is a tool for updating your beliefs in the face of evidence, which can help you make better predictions about the world. To quote [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superforecasting _Superforecasting_], a book about people who are inordinately good at predicting the future: > The superforecasters are a numerate bunch: many know about Bayes' theorem and could deploy it if they felt it was worth the trouble. But they rarely crunch the numbers so explicitly. What matters far more to the superforecasters than Bayes' theorem is Bayes' core insight of gradually getting closer to the truth by constantly updating in proportion to the weight of the evidence.

— Philip Tetlock and Dan Gardner, _Superforecasting_ The pages below teach that core insight. ## The laws of reasoning Imagine that, as part of a clinical study, you're being tested for a rare form of cancer, which affects 1 in 10,000 people. You have no reason to believe that you are more or less likely than average to have this form of cancer. You're administered a test which is 99% accurate, both in terms of [-specificity] and [-sensitivity]: It _correctly_ detects the cancer (in patients who have it) 99% of the time, and it _incorrectly_ detects cancer (in patients who don't have it) only 1% of the time. The test results come back positive. What's the chance that you have cancer? Bayes' rule says that the answer is precisely a 1 in 101.0101... chance, which is a probability a little below 1%. The remarkable thing about this is that there is only one answer: the odds of you having that type of cancer, given the above information, is _exactly_ 1 in 101.0101...; no more, no less. This is one of the key insights of Bayes' rule: Given what you knew, and what you saw, the maximally accurate state of belief for you to be in is completely pinned down, and while it's quite difficult to find in principle, we know how to find it in practice. Humanity has uncovered some of the laws of reasoning, and they are captured by Bayes' rule. If you want your beliefs to become more as you observe the world, Bayes' rule gives some hints about what you need to do. ## Learn Bayes' rule [todo: Make sure that the clickbaits on these articles match the explanations here. (If this text is better than the clickbait, replace the clickbait, and vice versa.)] - [1x5 __Bayes' rule: Odds form.__] Bayes' rule is simple, if you think in terms of [1rb odds ratios]. - [1zm __Bayes' rule: Proportional form.__] The fastest way to say something both convincing and true about belief-updating. - [1zh __Bayes' rule: Log-odds form.__] A variant of Bayes' rule that reveals tools for measuring the strength of a belief, or of a piece of evidence. - [554 __Bayes' rule: Probabilistic form.__] The original formulation of Bayes' rule. - [1zj __Bayes' rule: Functional form.__] Bayes' rule for [continuity continuous] variables. - [1zg __Bayes' rule: Vector form.__] For when you want to apply Bayes' rule to lots of evidence and lots of variables, all in one go. ## Implications of Bayes' rule - [220 __A Bayesian view of scientific virtues.__] Why is it that science relies on scientists who make bold, precise, and falsifiable predictions? Because of Bayes' rule, of course. - [update_by_inches __Update by inches.__] It's virtuous to change your mind in response to overwhelming evidence. It's even more virtuous to shift your beliefs a little bit at a time, in response to *all* evidence (no matter how small). - [1y6 __Belief revision as probability elimination.__] Update your beliefs by throwing away large chunks of probability mass. - [552 __Shift towards the hypothesis of least surprise.__] When you see new evidence, ask: Which hypothesis is *least surprised?* - [4pk __Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.__] The people who adamantly claim they were abducted by aliens do provide *some* evidence for aliens. They just don't provide quantitatively *enough* evidence. - [ __Ideal reasoning via Bayes' rule.__] Bayes' rule is to reasoning as the Carnot cycle is to engines: Nobody can be a perfect Bayesian, but Bayesian reasoning is still the theoretical ideal. ## Related content - [4vr __Subjective probability.__] Probability is in the mind, not the world. If you don't know whether a tossed coin came up heads or tails, that's a fact about you, not a fact about the coin. - [1bv __Probability theory.__] The quantification and study of objects that represent uncertainty about the world, and methods for making those representations more accurate. - [3qq __Information theory.__] The quantification and study of information, communication, and what it means for one object to tell us about another.

1ln.editSummary: alias. note to self: come back and explain new requisites system.
1ln.title: Arbital requisites
1ln.clickbait: To understand a thing you often need to understand some other things.

1lw.title: Mathematics
1lw.clickbait: Mathematics is the study of numbers and other ideal objects that can be described by axioms.

1lz.title: Bayes' rule
1lz.clickbait: Bayes' rule is the core theorem of probability theory saying how to revise our beliefs when we make a new observation.

1rd.title: Mutually exclusive and exhaustive
1rd.clickbait: The condition needed for probabilities to sum to 1

1rf.title: Probability
1rf.clickbait: The degree to which someone believes something, measured on a scale from 0 to 1, allowing us to do math to it.

1rj.title: Conditional probability
1rj.clickbait: The notation for writing "The probability that someone has green eyes, if we know that they have red hair."

1rk.title: Normalization (probability)
1rk.clickbait: That thingy we do to make sure our probabilities sum to 1, when they should sum to 1.

1rm.title: Prior probability
1rm.clickbait: What we believed before seeing the evidence.

1rp.title: Posterior probability
1rp.clickbait: What we believe, after seeing the evidence and doing a Bayesian update.

1rq.title: Relative likelihood
1rq.clickbait: How relatively likely an observation is, given two or more hypotheses, determines the strength and direction of evidence.

1rt.title: Arbital path
1rt.clickbait: Arbital path is a linear sequence of pages tailored specifically to teach a given concept to a user.

1wt.title: Bayes' rule examples
1wt.clickbait: Interesting problems solvable by Bayes' rule

1wy.title: Waterfall diagram
1wy.clickbait: Visualizing Bayes' rule as the mixing of probability streams.

1x5.title: Bayes' rule: Odds form
1x5.clickbait: The simplest and most easily understandable form of Bayes' rule uses relative odds.

1xr.title: Proof of Bayes' rule
1xr.clickbait: Proofs of Bayes' rule, with graphics

1y9.title: Probability notation for Bayes' rule
1y9.clickbait: The probability notation used in Bayesian reasoning

1zg.title: Bayes' rule: Vector form
1zg.clickbait: For when you want to apply Bayes' rule to lots of evidence and lots of variables, all in one go. (This is more or less how spam filters work.)

1zh.title: Bayes' rule: Log-odds form
1zh.clickbait: A simple transformation of Bayes' rule reveals tools for measuring degree of belief, and strength of evidence.

1zj.editSummary: Replacing an "of course" with a more explicit explanation.
1zj.title: Bayes' rule: Functional form
1zj.clickbait: Bayes' rule for to continuous variables.

1zm.editSummary: Fixing typo: "this from of" -> "this form of"
1zm.title: Bayes' rule: Proportional form
1zm.clickbait: The fastest way to say something both convincing and true about belief-updating.

22x.title: Strength of Bayesian evidence
22x.clickbait: From a Bayesian standpoint, the strength of evidence can be identified with its likelihood ratio.

3d.title: Arbital
3d.clickbait: Arbital is the place for crowdsourced, intuitive math explanations.

3hs.title: Author's guide to Arbital
3hs.clickbait: How to write intuitive, flexible content on Arbital.

3n.title: Arbital "parent" relationship
3n.clickbait: Parent-child relationship between pages implies a strong, inseparable connection.

4y7.editSummary: applied ER's change to the clickbait
4y7.title: C-Class
4y7.clickbait: This page has substantial content, but may not thoroughly cover the topic, may not meet style and prose standards, or may not explain the concept in a way the target audience will reliably understand.

553.title: Bayes' rule: Explore
553.text:
Bayes' rule is a tool for updating your beliefs in the face of evidence, which can help you make better predictions about the world. To quote [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superforecasting _Superforecasting_], a book about people who are inordinately good at predicting the future: > The superforecasters are a numerate bunch: many know about Bayes' theorem and could deploy it if they felt it was worth the trouble. But they rarely crunch the numbers so explicitly. What matters far more to the superforecasters than Bayes' theorem is Bayes' core insight of gradually getting closer to the truth by constantly updating in proportion to the weight of the evidence.

— Philip Tetlock and Dan Gardner, _Superforecasting_ The pages below teach that core insight. ## The laws of reasoning Imagine that, as part of a clinical study, you're being tested for a rare form of cancer, which affects 1 in 10,000 people. You have no reason to believe that you are more or less likely than average to have this form of cancer. You're administered a test which is 99% accurate, both in terms of [-specificity] and [-sensitivity]: It _correctly_ detects the cancer (in patients who have it) 99% of the time, and it _incorrectly_ detects cancer (in patients who don't have it) only 1% of the time. The test results come back positive. What's the chance that you have cancer? Bayes' rule says that the answer is precisely a 1 in 101.0101... chance, which is a probability a little below 1%. The remarkable thing about this is that there is only one answer: the odds of you having that type of cancer, given the above information, is _exactly_ 1 in 101.0101...; no more, no less. This is one of the key insights of Bayes' rule: Given what you knew, and what you saw, the maximally accurate state of belief for you to be in is completely pinned down, and while it's quite difficult to find in principle, we know how to find it in practice. Humanity has uncovered some of the laws of reasoning, and they are captured by Bayes' rule. If you want your beliefs to become more as you observe the world, Bayes' rule gives some hints about what you need to do. ## Learn Bayes' rule [todo: Make sure that the clickbaits on these articles match the explanations here. (If this text is better than the clickbait, replace the clickbait, and vice versa.)] - [1x5 __Bayes' rule: Odds form.__] Bayes' rule is simple, if you think in terms of [1rb odds ratios]. - [1zm __Bayes' rule: Proportional form.__] The fastest way to say something both convincing and true about belief-updating. - [1zh __Bayes' rule: Log-odds form.__] A variant of Bayes' rule that reveals tools for measuring the strength of a belief, or of a piece of evidence. - [554 __Bayes' rule: Probabilistic form.__] The original formulation of Bayes' rule. - [1zj __Bayes' rule: Functional form.__] Bayes' rule for [continuity continuous] variables. - [1zg __Bayes' rule: Vector form.__] For when you want to apply Bayes' rule to lots of evidence and lots of variables, all in one go. ## Implications of Bayes' rule - [220 __A Bayesian view of scientific virtues.__] Why is it that science relies on scientists who make bold, precise, and falsifiable predictions? Because of Bayes' rule, of course. - [update_by_inches __Update by inches.__] It's virtuous to change your mind in response to overwhelming evidence. It's even more virtuous to shift your beliefs a little bit at a time, in response to *all* evidence (no matter how small). - [1y6 __Belief revision as probability elimination.__] Update your beliefs by throwing away large chunks of probability mass. - [552 __Shift towards the hypothesis of least surprise.__] When you see new evidence, ask: Which hypothesis is *least surprised?* - [4pk __Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.__] The people who adamantly claim they were abducted by aliens do provide *some* evidence for aliens. They just don't provide quantitatively *enough* evidence. - [ __Ideal reasoning via Bayes' rule.__] Bayes' rule is to reasoning as the Carnot cycle is to engines: Nobody can be a perfect Bayesian, but Bayesian reasoning is still the theoretical ideal. ## Related content - [4vr __Subjective probability.__] Probability is in the mind, not the world. If you don't know whether a tossed coin came up heads or tails, that's a fact about you, not a fact about the coin. - [1bv __Probability theory.__] The quantification and study of objects that represent uncertainty about the world, and methods for making those representations more accurate. - [3qq __Information theory.__] The quantification and study of information, communication, and what it means for one object to tell us about another.
